qas.question: What school of thought saw emotion as an impediment to virtue?
What thinker believed that emotions were necessary for virtue?
What did the Aristotelians call emotions?
Who was a notable scholastic thinker?
Along with Descartes, Machiavelli and Hume, what notable philosopher developed a theory of emotions?
What school of thought saw emotion as not an impediment to virtue?
What thinker believed that emotions weren't necessary for virtue?
What did the Aristotelians not call emotions?
Who wasn't a notable scholastic thinker?

context: Western philosophy regarded emotion in varying ways. In <a0_0><b5_0>stoic<b5_0/><a0_0/> theories it was seen as a hindrance to reason and therefore a hindrance to virtue. <a1_0><b6_0>Aristotle<b6_0/><a1_0/> believed that emotions were an essential component of virtue. In the Aristotelian view all emotions (called <a2_0><b7_0>passions<b7_0/><a2_0/>) corresponded to appetites or capacities. During the Middle Ages, the Aristotelian view was adopted and further developed by scholasticism and <a3_0><b8_0>Thomas Aquinas<b8_0/><a3_0/> in particular. There are also theories of emotions in the works of philosophers such as René Descartes, Niccolò Machiavelli, <a4_0>Baruch Spinoza<a4_0/> and David Hume. In the 19th century emotions were considered adaptive and were studied more frequently from an empiricist psychiatric perspective.
